case_name: Balak Ram, Nathoo, Dr. R. P. Kohli and Mohd. Sayeed Khan Banney Khan v. State

facts.text: On May 27, 1971 two persons called Tribeni Sahai and Radhey were shot dead in the town of Dataganj, District Budaun.

anchor.surface_text: On May 27, 1971 two persons called Tribeni Sahai and Radhey were shot dead in the town of Dataganj, District Budaun. The four appellants Balak Ram, Nathoo, Dr. R. P. Kohli and Mohd. Sayeed Khan Banney Khan were tried along with two others by the learned Sessions Judge, Budaun, for various offences in connection with that incident.

facts.text: Balak Ram was convicted under section 302 of the Penal Code and was sentenced to death by Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Balak Ram was convicted under section 302 of the Penal Code and was sentenced to death. He was also convicted and sentenced under section 337 read with section 149 for causing injuries to Jhilmili and Ram Prakash and under section 148, Penal Code.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted the other five accused including Nathoo, Dr. R. P. Kohli, Mohd. Sayeed Khan Banney Khan and Kailash.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judge acquitted the other five accused of all the charges. Out of these five, we are concerned with Kailash whose acquittal is now under challenge and with Ahmed Sayeed Khan alias Pearey Mian who died during the pendency of the proceedings in the High Court of Allahabad.

facts.text: High Court by Judgment dated December 22, 1972 confirmed conviction of Balak Ram under section 302 and death sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its Judgment dated December 22, 1972 confirmed the conviction of Balak Ram and the sentence of death imposed on him under section 302 as also his conviction under section 148.

facts.text: High Court convicted Nathoo, Dr. R. P. Kohli and Mohd. Sayeed Khan Banney Khan under sections 302 and 307 read with section 149.

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal against the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions Court, the High Court confirmed the acquittal of Kailash, but convicted Nathoo, Dr. R. P. Kohli and Mohd. Sayeed Khan Banney Khan under sections 302 and 307 read with section 149.

facts.text: Incident arose out of political rivalry between Congress R, Congress O and Bhartiya Jan Sangh.

anchor.surface_text: The incident leading to the murder of Tribeni Sahai and Radhey arose, indisputably, out of political rivalry, the parties involved being the Congress R , Congress O and the Bhartiya Jan Sangh.

facts.text: Tribeni Sahai was a sitting Member of the U.P. Legislative Assembly, elected on the Congress R ticket.

anchor.surface_text: Tribeni Sahai was a sitting Member of the U.P. Legislative Assembly, elected on the Congress, R ticket while the other victim Radhey is said to have been his bodyguard.

facts.text: Elections to the Town Area Committee of Dataganj scheduled on May 30, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The elections to the Town Area Committee of Dataganj were scheduled to be held on May 30, 1971.

facts.text: Balak Ram contesting election to Chairmanship as nominee of Congress O.

anchor.surface_text: Balak Ram was contesting the election to the Chairmanship of the Committee as a nominee of Congress O .

facts.text: District Magistrate promulgated order under section 144 CrPC on May 24, 1971 prohibiting assembly of more than five persons and carrying arms.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate of Badaun, therefore, promulgated on May 24, 1971 an order under section 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, prohibiting the assembly of more than five persons and carrying of arms in public.

facts.text: Balak Ram led a procession of 25 persons at 6.30 p.m. on May 27, 1971 in defiance of section 144 order.

anchor.surface_text: In defiance of this order, Balak Ram led a procession of some 25 persons at about 6.30 p.m. on May 27, 1971.

facts.text: At about 9.15 p.m. on May 27, six accused with 15-20 followers went canvassing and then towards Tribeni Sahai's house.

anchor.surface_text: At about 9.15 p.m. on May 27 the six accused along with 15 or 20 of their followers went about canvassing for the candidates put up by the Congress O .

facts.text: Balak Ram fired a shot at Tribeni Sahai with licensed pistol, hitting right scapular region.

anchor.surface_text: Balak Ram stepped out, stood on the raised ground to the east of the lane and fired a shot at Tribeni Sahai with a licensed pistol which he was carrying.

facts.text: Radhey received pistol injury on left back from shots by Balak Ram, Nathoo and Dr. Kohli.

anchor.surface_text: Radhey Who was a few paces behind Tribeni Sahai ran forward to protect him when Balak Ram, Nathoo and Dr. Kohli fired four or five shots.. Radhey received a pistol injury on the left back.

facts.text: Jhilmili received injury on left thigh, Ram Prakash superficial burn on right abdomen from shots by Balak Ram, Nathoo, Dr. Kohli.

anchor.surface_text: Jhilmili and Ram Prakash who live nearby came running in protest but they also received injuries as a result of the shots fired by Balak Ram, Nathoo and Dr. Kohli.

facts.text: Rajendra Kumar Misra gave information at 9.45 p.m. on May 27 at police station.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution, Rajendra Kumar Misra gave information of the incident at 9.45 p.m. at the police station which is about two furlongs away.

facts.text: Tribeni Sahai died at 8.30 p.m. on May 28, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Tribeni Sahai was thereafter taken to the Mission Hospital at Barielly but he succumbed to his injury at 8.30 p.m. on the 28.

facts.text: Radhey declared dead at Civil Hospital Budaun at 11.30 p.m. on May 27.

anchor.surface_text: The two cars reached the Civil Hospital at Budaun at 11.30 p.m. ... Radhey, on being taken out of the car, was declared dead while Tribeni Sahai was taken to the Emergency Ward.

facts.text: Ballistic expert opined bullet from Radhey's body fired from Balak Ram's pistol.

anchor.surface_text: The ballistic expert, Shyam Narain, opined that the bullet recovered from Radheys body was fired from Balak Rams pistol but that the bullet seized from the scene of occurrence was fired from some other weapon.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside conviction of Nathoo, Dr. Kohli and Banney Khan, acquitted them.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the order of conviction and sentence passed by the High Court against Nathoo, Dr. R. P. Kohli and Mohammad Sayeed Khan alias Banney Khan is set aside and their appeals are allowed.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld conviction and death sentence of Balak Ram.

anchor.surface_text: Balak Rams conviction must, therefore, stand. On the question of sentence, there is no reason for interference.

facts.text: Balak Ram, Nathoo and Banney Khan belonged to Congress O.

anchor.surface_text: Balak Ram, Nathoo and Banney Khan belonged to the Congress O while Dr. R. P. Kohli was the local President of the Jan Sangh.

facts.text: Dr. R. P. Kohli was local President of Jan Sangh.

anchor.surface_text: Balak Ram, Nathoo and Banney Khan belonged to the Congress O while Dr. R. P. Kohli was the local President of the Jan Sangh.

facts.text: Nathoo and Banney Khan contesting membership of Town Area Committee on Congress O ticket.

anchor.surface_text: Nathoo and Banney Khan were contesting the election for the membership of the Committee on the ticket of Congress O .

facts.text: Balak Ram pleaded alibi, claimed at Lucknow from May 25.

anchor.surface_text: Balak Ram pleaded alibi saying that he was at Lucknow from May 25. He led evidence in support of his plea of alibi,

The State of U.P. this Court held after a review of previous authorities that if the High Court has set aside an order of acquittal the Supreme Court in an appeal under Article 136 will examine the evidence only if the High Court has failed to apply correctly the principles governing appeals against acquittal.

concepts.interpretation: HC has full powers as in conviction appeals, but if two reasonable views possible, should not interfere with trial court's acquittal.

A criminal case was then filed against Banney Khan and Pearey Mian under section 307, Penal Code, for a murderous assault on one Suleman
On August 3, 1970 Pearey Mian had lodged report against Tribeni Sahai and his bodyguard Radhey under section 394, Penal Code.
Tribeni Sahai had also instituted a case under section 107, Criminal Procedure Code, against Ram Prakashs father and others.

issues.text: whether the High Court was justified in upholding the conviction of Balak Ram and the sentence of death imposed on him by the Sessions Court

anchor.surface_text: Broadly, the two questions which arise for consideration are whether the High Court was justified in upholding the conviction of Balak Ram and the sentence of death imposed on him by the Sessions Court

issues.text: whether the High Court had good and sufficient reasons for interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions Court in favour of Nathoo, Dr. Kohli and Banney Khan

anchor.surface_text: and secondly whether the High Court had good and sufficient reasons for interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions Court in favour of Nathoo, Dr. Kohli and Banney Khan.

issues.text: whether the High Court was justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed in favour of Nathoo, Dr. Kohli and Banney Khan by the Sessions Court

anchor.surface_text: the question for consideration is whether the High Court was justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed in their favour by the Sessions Court.

issues.text: whether the eye-witnesses including the injured Jhilmili and Ram Prakash could be relied upon unless independent corroboration was available to their testimony

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge, Budaun, came to the conclusion that none of the eye-witnesses including the injured Jhilmili and Ram Prakash could be relied upon unless independent corroboration was available to their testimony.

issues.text: whether it is safe to act on the uncorroborated dying declaration of Tribeni Sahai

anchor.surface_text: All the same, one must face the question whether, in the circumstances of the case, it is safe to act on the uncorroborated dying declaration of Tribeni Sahai

issues.text: whether there is reason for interference with the sentence of death imposed on Balak Ram

anchor.surface_text: On the question of sentence, there is no reason for interference.

arguments.claim: Appellants were falsely implicated on account of political rivalry.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellants, broadly, was that they were falsely implicated on account of political rivalry. They contended that the witnesses had given false evidence against them either because they were friends or relatives of Tribeni Sahai or because of the pressure exerted on them by the police at the instance, partly, of Tribeni Sahais brother Radhey Shyam, who was the Deputy Inspector General of Police and a Member of the Vigilance Commission, U.P.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is alleged to have been given by Dr. Kohli and others that Balak Ram should fire. It is im- possible that Jhilmili companyld have jumped into the fir

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agrees witnesses unreliable due to political bias, lack independent corroboration, leading to acquittal of three appellants.

arguments.claim: Balak Ram was at Lucknow from May 25, alibi.

anchor.surface_text: Balak Ram pleaded alibi saying that he was at Lucknow from May 25. He led evidence in support of his plea of alibi, Nathoo admitted that he was related to Balak Ram but contended that he was contesting the election to the membership of the Town Area Committee as an independent candidate.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rejected based on concurrent findings and ballistic evidence linking pistol to injury.

arguments.claim: Nathoo went to Chandausi on morning of 27th, returned 29th, feared shooting order by DIG.

anchor.surface_text: He also pleaded alibi saying that he had gone to Chandausi on the morning of 27th and returned to Dataganj on May 29. He stated that he wanted to surrender earlier but being informed that Radhey Shyam, D.I.G., had issued orders for shooting the accused, if found, he could not surrender till June 7.

anchor.surface_text: Each of the appellants denied knowledge of the order passed by the District Magistrate under section 144, Criminal Procedure Code and each one denied his presence in the procession which was taken out at about 6.30 p.m. on the 27th.

arguments.claim: Dying declarations unreliable without corroboration.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge took the same view about the dying declarations alleged to have been made by Tribeni Sahai. Except for Balak Ram, the other accused were acquitted by the learned Judge as independent corroboration was not available to the evidence of the witnesses in regard to the part played by those accused.

arguments.claim: Balak Ram convicted based on ballistic corroboration to eyewitness and dying decl.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as Balak Ram is concerned, the learned Judge convicted him for the murder of Tribeni Sahai and Radhey on the view that the evidence of the eye-witnesses and the dying declarations of Tribeni Sahai were corroborated by the opinion of the Ballistic Expert, Shyam Narain, who stated that the bullet recovered from the dead body of Radhey was fired from Balak Rams pistol.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Loki and Ganga Ram whose names were mentioned in the F.I.R. were number examined and therefore an adverse inference should be drawn against the prose

arguments.court_reasoning: Concurrent finding, ballistic links pistol to Radhey's fatal bullet.

arguments.claim: Jhilmili and Ram Prakash independent witnesses, corroborate each other and Rajendra Kumar.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the evidence of Jhilmili and Ram Prakash who, according to it, were independent witnesses. The two witnesses were said to corroborate each other individually and together they were held to corroborate the evidence of Rajendra Kumar Misra.

arguments.claim: Dying declarations true, voluntary, full corroboration.

arguments.claim: SC does not interfere with concurrent findings unless exceptional circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The powers of the Supreme Court under Article 136 are wide but in criminal appeals this Court does not interfere with the concurrent findings of fact save in exceptional circumstances.

arguments.claim: No re-appraisal unless legal process disregarded, natural justice violated, grave injustice.

anchor.surface_text: This Court would not therefore re-appraise the evidence unless, for example, the forms of legal process are disregarded or principles of natural justice are violated or substantial and grave injustice has otherwise resulted.

arguments.claim: In appeal against acquittal, SC examines only if HC misapplied principles.

anchor.surface_text: In Ram Jag and Ors. v. The State of U.P. this Court held after a review of previous authorities that if the High Court has set aside an order of acquittal the Supreme Court in an appeal under Article 136 will examine the evidence only if the High Court has failed to apply correctly the principles governing appeals against acquittal.

arguments.claim: HC full powers in acquittal appeals, but if two reasonable views, should not interfere.

anchor.surface_text: It was held in that case that the powers of the High Court are as full and wide in appeals against acquittal as in appeal against conviction but, amongst things, if two views of the evidence are reasonably possible the High Court ought not to interfere with the order of acquittal passed by the trial court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: data, is insufficient to absolve the prosecution from its duty to examine wit nesses whose evidence is necessary for upholding its case. A large numbe

arguments.court_reasoning: Two views possible, Sessions reasonable, HC erred in reversing acquittal.

arguments.claim: Jhilmili, Ram Prakash not reliable: FIR omission, family political links to accused, false denials.

anchor.surface_text: Jhilmilis sons sitting with accused group, son-in-law Congress O candidate, denied knowledge, bank deposit lies, injury story implausible. Similar for Ram Prakash: cases against father, unnatural conduct post-injury.

arguments.claim: Rajendra Kumar unreliable: partisan relative, FIR omissions deliberate, unnatural conduct.

anchor.surface_text: Omission of injured in FIR deliberate, did not check injuries, silent spectator, spot discrepancies, added names later.

arguments.claim: Aryendra Nath unreliable: doubtful residence, s.164 inconsistencies, added accused.

anchor.surface_text: Doubtful living at vantage house, s.164 mentioned more accused, incredible exhortation.

arguments.claim: s.164 statements tie witnesses, approach with caution.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court overlooked that the evidence of witnesses whose statements are recorded under section 164 must be approached with caution. Such witnesses feel tied to their previous statements given on oath and have but a theoretical freedom to depart from the earlier version.

arguments.claim: Dying declarations unreliable: first unwitnessed by PWs, second by IO improper (no witnesses, sig), third maker unfit, influenced.

anchor.surface_text: Not much reliance on first two. Second: IO haste, no sigs, violates Rule 115 UP Police Regs. Third: shock, pain, bleeding, no fit state; surrounded by friends like Dharam Pal.

arguments.claim: Two reasonable views possible re Nathoo, Kohli, Banney; HC should not reverse acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid discussion of the various items of evidence must at least yield the result that the conclusion to which the learned Sessions Judge came was a reasonable conclusion to come to. It cannot be denied that two views of the evidence are reasonably possible in regard to the participation of Nathoo, Dr. Kohli and Banney Khan.

arguments.claim: No ballistic link to Kohli revolver or others.

anchor.surface_text: A revolver was recovered from the house of Dr. Kohli... none of the five empties recovered from the scene of offence could have been fired from Dr. Kohlis revolver.

arguments.claim: Loki, Ganga Ram not examined, adverse inference; FIR ante-dated; site plan vague; no motive considered; defence evidence ignored.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged that Loki and Ganga Ram whose names were mentioned in the F.I.R. were not examined and therefore an adverse inference should be drawn against the prosecution that the relevant columns in the Inquest Report were deliberately left blank so as to facilitate a manipulation of evidence, that the F.I.R. was ante-dated...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Loki and Ganga Ram whose names were mentioned in the F.I.R. were number examined and therefore an adverse inference should be drawn against the prose

arguments.court_reasoning: Points answered earlier, concurrent finding for Balak Ram stands.

arguments.claim: Ballistic evidence corroborates Balak Ram's guilt for Radhey's death.

anchor.surface_text: The ballistic expert, Shyam Narain, opined that the bullet recovered from Radheys body was fired from Balak Rams pistol but that the bullet seized from the scene of occurrence was fired from some other weapon.

arguments.claim: HC must independently examine evidence in death sentence confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: In a reference for confirmation of the death sentence under sec. 374, Criminal Procedure Code, the High Court must examine the entire evidence for itself, independently of the Sessions Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: vidence of the defence witnesses at all which it was its duty to companysider in a reference under section 374, Criminal Procedure Code. The more impo

arguments.court_reasoning: HC did, but SC upholds as no miscarriage.

arguments.claim: No reason to interfere with death sentence: armed with pistol, no provocation.

anchor.surface_text: Balak Rams conviction must, therefore, stand. On the question of sentence, there is no reason for interference. Balak Ram was carrying a pistol and he fired from that pistol without any provocation either from Tribeni Sahai or from Radhey.

holdings.text: The powers of the Supreme Court under Article 136 are wide but in criminal appeals this Court does not interfere with the concurrent findings of fact save in exceptional circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The powers of the Supreme Court under Article 136 are wide but in criminal appeals this Court does not interfere with the concurrent findings of fact save in exceptional circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court states general principle limiting interference under Art 136 to exceptional cases like disregard of legal process or grave injustice.

holdings.text: This Court would not therefore re-appraise the evidence unless, for example, the forms of legal process are disregarded or principles of natural justice are violated or substantial and grave injustice has otherwise resulted.

anchor.surface_text: This Court would not therefore re-appraise the evidence unless, for example, the forms of legal process are disregarded or principles of natural justice are violated or substantial and grave injustice has otherwise resulted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies precedent from Ramabhupala Reddy to justify no re-appraisal for Balak Ram's concurrent conviction.

holdings.text: If the High Court has set aside an order of acquittal the Supreme Court in an appeal under Article 136 will examine the evidence only if the High Court has failed to apply correctly the principles governing appeals against acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: In Ram Jag and Ors. v. The State of U.P. this Court held after a review of previous authorities that if the High Court has set aside an order of acquittal the Supreme Court in an appeal under Article 136 will examine the evidence only if the High Court has failed to apply correctly the principles governing appeals against acquittal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Ram Jag precedent; finds HC misapplied principles by reversing acquittal despite two reasonable views.

holdings.text: The powers of the High Court are as full and wide in appeals against acquittal as in appeal against conviction but, amongst things, if two views of the evidence are reasonably possible the High Court ought not to interfere with the order of acquittal passed by the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: It was held in that case that the powers of the High Court are as full and wide in appeals against acquittal as in appeal against conviction but, amongst things, if two views of the evidence are reasonably possible the High Court ought not to interfere with the order of acquittal passed by the trial court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Ram Jag; Sessions acquittal reasonable due to lack of corroboration, so HC reversal unjustified.

holdings.text: The learned Sessions Judge was right for some of these reasons in holding that the evidence of Jhilmili and Ram Prakash could not be accepted without independent corroboration.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge was right for some of these reasons in holding that the evidence of Jhilmili and Ram Prakash could not be accepted without independent corroboration. The High Court treated them as independent witnesses and held that they had corroborated each other.

holdings.reasoning_summary: After detailing infirmities (partisan links, omissions, unnatural conduct), accepts Sessions view requiring independent corroboration in partisan case.

holdings.text: We find it impossible to accept the conclusion of the High Court that All the three dying declarations of Sri Tribeni Sahai provide full corroboration...

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we find it impossible to accept the conclusion of the High Court that All the three dying declarations of Sri Tribeni Sahai provide full corroboration to the testimony of the two injured eyewitnesses and Aryendra that it was Balak Ram, who was responsible for the fatal injury to Sri Tribeni Sahai...

holdings.reasoning_summary: First two flawed (no witnesses, procedural lapses per Rule 115); third: maker unfit (shock, pain), influenced by friends; uncorroborated.

holdings.text: The aforesaid discussion of the various items of evidence must at least yield the result that the conclusion to which the learned Sessions Judge came was a reasonable conclusion to come to. It cannot be denied that two views of the evidence are reasonably possible in regard to the participation of Nathoo, Dr. Kohli and Banney Khan. the High Court, therefore, ought not to have interfered with the judgment of the Sessions Court in their favour.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid discussion of the various items of evidence must at least yield the result that the conclusion to which the learned Sessions Judge came was a reasonable conclusion to come to. It cannot be denied that two views of the evidence are reasonably possible in regard to the participation of Nathoo, Dr. Kohli and Banney Khan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eyewitnesses unreliable without independent corr; no ballistic link; exhortation artificial; applies two-views principle.

holdings.text: In the result the order of conviction and sentence passed by the High Court against Nathoo, Dr. R. P. Kohli and Mohammad Sayeed Khan alias Banney Khan is set aside and their appeals are allowed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the order of conviction and sentence passed by the High Court against Nathoo, Dr. R. P. Kohli and Mohammad Sayeed Khan alias Banney Khan is set aside and their appeals are allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reliable evidence of participation; reasonable doubt favors acquittal.

holdings.text: Balak Rams conviction must, therefore, stand.

anchor.surface_text: Balak Rams conviction must, therefore, stand. On the question of sentence, there is no reason for interference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings; ballistic expert links pistol to fatal bullet in Radhey; eyewitness/dying decl corroborated specifically for him; alibi rejected.

holdings.text: On the question of sentence, there is no reason for interference.

anchor.surface_text: Balak Rams conviction must, therefore, stand. On the question of sentence, there is no reason for interference. Balak Ram was carrying a pistol and he fired from that pistol without any provocation either from Tribeni Sahai or from Radhey.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Armed with pistol, fired without provocation; no mitigating factors; upholds death sentence.

holdings.text: In a reference for confirmation of the death sentence under sec. 374, Criminal Procedure Code, the High Court must examine the entire evidence for itself, independently of the Sessions Court.

anchor.surface_text: In a reference for confirmation of the death sentence under sec. 374, Criminal Procedure Code, the High Court must examine the entire evidence for itself, independently of the Sessions Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Bhupendra Singh and Jamman; notes HC did examine but no miscarriage.
